{{Infobox person | name = Astolphe de Custine | image = Custine.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Astolphe-Louis-Léonor, Marquis de Custine | birth_date = 18 March 1790 | birth_place = [[Niderviller]], France | death_date = 25 September 1857 | death_place = Paris, France | resting_place = Chapelle d'Auquainville, [[Auquainville]], [[Calvados (department)|Calvados]], [[Lower Normandy]], France | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | education = }} '''Astolphe-Louis-Léonor, Marquis de Custine''' (18 March 1790 – 25 September 1857) was a French [[Aristocracy (class)|aristocrat]] and writer who is best known for his [[travel writing]], in particular his account of his visit to Russia, ''La Russie en 1839''. This work documents not only Custine's travels through the Russian Empire, but also the social fabric, economy and way of life during the reign of [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]. ==Biography== [[File:Delphine de Custine.jpg|thumb|left|Delphine de Custine]] Astolphe de Custine was born in [[Niderviller]], [[Lorrain (province)|Lorraine]]. His family belonged to the [[French nobility]] and possessed the title [[marquis]] since the early 18th century. The paternal branch of the family also owned a famous [[faience]] factory. His mother, Delphine de Sabran, Marquise de Custine, also came from a prestigious family and was noted for her intelligence and great beauty. Custine's father and [[Adam Philippe, Comte de Custine|grandfather]] both sympathized with the [[French Revolution]] but were both [[guillotine]]d. Custine's mother was imprisoned and barely escaped the same fate. In the aftermath of the overthrow of [[Maximilien Robespierre|Robespierre]] and the end of the [[Reign of Terror]], the friendship of the marchioness with [[Joseph Fouché]] (who would eventually become Minister of Police under [[Napoleon I|Napoleon]]) allowed her to recover part of the family fortune. Custine and his mother resettled in Lorraine in 1795. Under the direction of his strong-willed mother, Custine was raised in an chaotic yet stimulating social environment. This brought him into frequent contact with noted intellectuals, among them [[Germaine de Staël]] and [[François-René de Chateaubriand]],{{cite web |url = http://www.oxonianreview.org/issues/2-2/2-2-3.htm |title = Reviews: The Marquis de Custine and the question of Russian history |accessdate = 5 February 2009 |year = 2002 |publisher = [[The Oxonian Review]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090106201439/http://www.oxonianreview.org/issues/2-2/2-2-3.htm |archivedate = 6 January 2009 |df = }} considered the founder of [[Romanticism]] in [[French literature]]. The marchioness purchased the château of Fervaques, near [[Lisieux]], in [[Normandy]], from the [[Anne-Adrien-Pierre de Montmorency-Laval|Duc de Laval]] in October 1803; Chateaubriand noted his visits there between 1804 and 1806 in which he discussed with both the marchioness and Custine in ''[[Mémoires d'Outre-Tombe]]''. Delphine died at [[Bex]], in Vaud, Switzerland, July 13, 1826. Custine was given an excellent education and seemed to be headed towards a life in society. An income of 60,000 francs a year enabled him to live as he pleased. He owned an estate outside Paris, at Saint-Gratien, where on occasions he was visited by [[Frédéric Chopin]].{{Cite web|url=http://observer.com/1999/11/a-french-marquis-adventures-dandy-stuff-for-biography/|title=A French Marquis’ Adventures: Dandy Stuff for Biography|date=1999-11-22|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-19}} Custine spent time in the diplomatic service, attending the [[Congress of Vienna]], and even accepted a military commission. In 1821 Custine married Léontine de Saint-Simon de Courtomer, following the wishes of his mother. The Marquis, who would later admit his [[homosexuality]] and live openly with a male lover, was nevertheless genuinely fond of his wife. They had a son, Enguerrand. During the marriage Custine met and established a romantic relationship with an Englishman, Edward Saint-Barbe, who moved into the house with the couple, and remained his life companion.[[Anka Muhlstein]], "A Taste For Freedom: The Life of Astolphe de Custine", Helen Marx Books, 1999, pp184-186, p261 In 1823, during the early stages of a second pregnancy, Léontine fell ill and died, aged only twenty. On 28 October 1824, Custine's life was irrevocably changed. That night, he was found unconscious in the mud outside of Paris, stripped to the waist, having been beaten and robbed. The attack had been carried out by a group of soldiers; with one of whom Custine allegedly had attempted to have a sexual encounter.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/16/weekinreview/word-for-word-marquis-de-custine-long-ago-look-russia-so-what-else-new.html|title=Word for Word/The Marquis de Custine;A Long-Ago Look at Russia: (So What Else Is New?)|last=Erlanger|first=Steven|date=1996-06-16|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-08-19}} However the exact reason for the attack was never proven. Nevertheless, news of the incident quickly spread around France — "From this time on to the end of his life Custine would figure, in the cruel gossip of the day, primarily as France's most distinguished and notorious homosexual." Even though the literary salons, as opposed to the society salons, remained open to Custine, many people who were friendly with him sneered at him behind his back. His diplomatic career was also cut short by this incident. A few years later, in 1826, several family friends would die, as well as Custine's young son Enguerrand (born 1822), by his late wife, and his mother. In the years after these tragedies, Custine became very pious. Custine gravitated toward the [[Romanticism|Romantic]] movement and spent the next few years writing [[poetry]] and [[novel]]s. Custine wrote one play and purchased a theater to produce it, but the play closed after three performances. None of his literary works received much attention. [[Heinrich Heine]] called Custine "un demi-[[homme des lettres]]" (a half-man of letters). In 1835, an extremely attractive Polish count, the twenty-three year old Ignatius Gurowski (1812–1887),Ruvigny et Raineval, Melville Henry Massue marquis de''The Blood Royal of Britain'', Genealogical Publishing Company, 1994, p87 moved into Custine and Saint-Barbe's home in the rue de La Rochefoucauld to form a ménage à trois. Wrote Custine: "He has an excellent heart, an original mind, is graciously ignorant of everything, and what settles it all, a charming bearing and countenance." The capricious Gurowski was not an easy guest, running up debts and seducing both men and women, but appears to have amused the couple. The detailed register of homosexuals, then maintained by the Paris police prefecture, and which termed Custine's inclinations 'frantic', wrote of Gurowski with a comical note of possible despair: "It is hereditary in his family: his father and grandfather were of the same religion."[[Laure Murat|Murat, Laure]] ''La tante, le policier et l'écrivain'' in ''Sexologie et théories savantes du sexe'', Revue d'Histoire des Sciences Humaines, 2007; https://www.cairn.info/revue-histoire-des-sciences-humaines-2007-2-page-47.htm In 1841 Gurowski married a Spanish infanta [[Isabella Ferdinanda de Bourbon]].''Almanacco della Real Corte di Lucca, 1847'', Tipgrafia Giusti, Luca 1847, p104 ==''La Russie en 1839''== Custine eventually discovered that his knack was for travel writing. He wrote a decently received account of a trip to Spain and was encouraged by [[Honoré de Balzac]] to write accounts of other "half-European" parts of Europe, like southern Italy and Russia. In the late 1830s, [[Alexis de Tocqueville]]'s ''[[Democracy in America]]'' appeared, whose last chapter contained the prophecy that the future belonged to Russia and [[United States|America]]. Inspired by Toqueville's work, Custine decided that Russia would be the subject of his next writing effort. Custine was later dubbed by some historians as "the de Tocqueville of Russia".{{cite web | last = Caplan | first = Bryan | authorlink = Bryan Caplan | coauthors = | date = | year = | month = | url = http://www.gmu.edu/departments/economics/bcaplan/museum/czar1.htm | title = Czarist Origins of Communism, I | work = Museum of Communism | pages = | publisher = | language = | accessdate = 2006-06-10}} Custine visited Russia in 1839, spending most of his time in [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]], but also visiting [[Moscow]] and [[Yaroslavl]]. A political reactionary in his own country, fearful that democracy would inevitably lead to mob rule, he went to Russia looking for arguments against [[representative government]], but he was appalled by autocracy as practiced in Russia and equally by the Russian people's apparent collaboration in their own oppression. He attributed this state of affairs to what he saw as the backwardness of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], combined with the disastrous effects of the [[Mongol invasion of Rus'|Mongol invasion of medieval Russia]], and the policies of [[Peter the Great]]. He was struck by the "smothering enormity of power and the randomness of everyday life and death". Custine criticized St. Petersburg for being the creation of one man and not the result of spontaneous historical forces. Custine, however, loved [[Moscow]] architecture and predicted that Russia would be a great power if its capital were ever moved back to the older city. Most of Custine's mockery was reserved for the [[Russian nobility]] and [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]. Custine said that Russia's aristocracy had "just enough of the gloss of European civilization to be 'spoiled as savages' but not enough to become cultivated men. They were like 'trained bears who made you long for the wild ones.'" Other tart and much-quoted observations included:
"In Russia, everything you notice, and everything that happens around you, has a terrifying uniformity; and the first thought that comes into the traveler's mind, as he contemplates this symmetry, is that such entire consistency and regularity, so contrary to the natural inclination of mankind, cannot have been achieved and could not survive without violence." "The nature of its Government is interference, negligence and corruption. You rebel against the notion that you could become accustomed to all this, yet you do become accustomed to it. In that country, a sincere man would be taken for an idiot." "A wealth of unnecessary and petty precautions here engenders a whole army of clerks, each of whom carries out his task with a degree of pedantry and inflexibility, and a self-important air solely designed to add significance to the least significant employment." "The profession of misleading foreigners is one known only in Russia....everyone disguises what is bad and shows what is good before the master's eyes."
Custine criticized Tsar Nicholas for the constant spying he ordered and for repressing Poland. Custine had more than one conversation with the [[Tsar]] and concluded it was possible that the Tsar behaved as he did only because he felt he had to. "If the [[Emperor]] has no more of mercy in his heart than he reveals in his policies, then I pity Russia; if, on the other hand, his true sentiments are really superior to his acts, then I pity the Emperor" (Kennan 76). Kennan describes Russia as a horrible domain of obsequious flattery of the Tsar and spying. Custine said the air felt freer the moment one crossed into [[Prussia]]. In the mid-20th century, many commentators drew parallels between Custine's description of Russia and contemporary Soviet Union as well as noticing many similarities between his character outline of Nicholas I and [[Joseph Stalin]]. ===Publication and reaction=== ''La Russie en 1839'' went through six printings and was widely read in England, France, and Germany but banned in Russia. Nevertheless, some books printed in France were smuggled in and made an impact on Russian society. From 1890 to 1891, fragments of the book were published in Russian journals. Poorly-abridged versions of the book were published in 1910 and in 1930 in the [[Soviet Union]]. Finally, an unabridged version was published in 1996. Several Russian authors published works critical of Custine's ''La Russie en 1839'', among them ''Un mot sur l'ouvrage de M. de Custine, intitulé: La Russie en 1839'' by Xavier Labenski ([[:fr:Jean Polonius|Jean Polonius]]) and ''Examen de l'ouvrage de M. le marquis de Custine intitulé "La Russie en 1839"'' (Paris, 1844) by [[Nicholas Gretsch]].https://books.google.com/books?id=JngJuw9__xsC&pg=PA348 Tsarist authorities also sponsored a more scholarly investigation of Russia by a foreigner, [[August von Haxthausen]], who authored the ''Studies on the Interior of Russia''.''Studien über die Zustände, das Volksleben, und insbesondere die ländlichen Einrichtungen Russlands'', the first two volumes published in 1847, with a third published in 1852. This work can be interpreted as an attempt to provide an objective research of Russia's traditional social institutions, which the Tsar's advisors believed would effectively counter Custine's work. ''Studies'' was translated from German into French and English in 1848.Fisher, David C. "Russia and the Crystal Palace 1851" in ''Britain, the Empire, and the World at the Great Exhibition of 1851'' ed. Jeffery A. Auerbach & Peter H. Hoffenberg. Ashgate, 2008: p. 124. The Tsar also commissioned the French writer [[Hippolyte Auger]] to pen an extensive refutation. However, as the scandal of Custine's work had subsided by then, the Tsar decided it was best not to remind the public of the book, and the project was abandoned.Tolley, Bruce ''A Saint-Simonian writer: Hippolyte Auger (1797–1881)'', Australian Journal of French Studies, Vol 11, Issue 3 ==Later life== Custine died of a stroke in the evening of 25 September 1857.Muhlstein, Anka, ''A Taste For Freedom: The Life of Astolphe de Custine", 1999, p378 ==Legacy== Custine's observations in ''La Russie en 1839'' continue to be admired for their insight, prescience and sheer entertaining value, but are also disliked by others for reasons that can include the belief they are inaccurate, pretentious, racist, and that the idea of national stereotypes is an absurdity. It has been suggested that he is one of the originators of a putative West European Russophobia.{{citation |title=The Eternal Collapse of Russia |first=Paul |last=Starobin |work=The National Interest |date=28 August 2014 |url=http://nationalinterest.org/feature/the-eternal-collapse-russia-11126}}{{citation |contribution=Russian Military Tourism |first=Susan |last=Layton |title=Turizm: The Russian and East European Tourist Under Capitalism and Socialism |editor-first=Anne E. |editor-last=Gorsuch |page=51 |publisher=Cornell University Press |year=2006 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=qe06_rwosg4C&pg=PA51&lpg=PA51&dq=de-custine+russophobe&source=bl&ots=rYXlgI_vas&sig=tj6bNyxHlvrVxajttcrPB1ik9BQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uQBXVLXHJoiayQSZsIHQBA&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=de-custine%20russophobe&f=false}} However, as one critic has written, what is indisputable is that "Above all, the Marquis valued freedom; freedom from fear, hypocrisy and the shackles that restrain the human spirit." A character representing Custine appears in the 2002 film ''[[Russian Ark]]''; his conversations with the time-travelling narrator are intended to reflect Russia's continued struggle to search for its own identity and define its relations vis-à-vis Europe. ==Notes and references== {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Christian Sigrist, ''Das Russlandbild des Marquis de Custine. Von der Zivilisationskritik zur Russlandfeindlichkeit'', Frankfurt 1990. * Irena Grudzinska Gross, ''The Scar of Revolution, Custine, Tocqueville, and the Romantic Imagination'', Berkeley 1991. * [[Anka Muhlstein]], ''A Taste For Freedom: The Life of Astolphe de Custine", 1999. Republished as: ''Astolphe de Custine: The Last French Aristocrat'', London 2001. * Astolphe de Custine, ''Journey For Our Time: The Journals of the Marquis de Custine''. Ed. Phyllis Penn Kohler, Washington 1987. * Astolphe de Custine, ''Journey For Our Time: The Journals of the Marquis de Custine''. Ed. Phyllis Penn Kohler, London 1951. * Astolphe de Custine, ''Empire of the Czar. A Journey Through Ethernal Russia'', Auklend 1989. * George F. Kennan, ''The Marquis de Custine and His Russia in 1839'', London 1972. * Albert Marie Pierre de Luppé, ''Astolphe de Custine'', Monaco 1957. * Francine-Dominique Liechtenhan, ''Astolphe de Custine voyageur et philosophe'', Paris 1990. * Julien Frédéric Tarn, ''Le Marquis de Custine ou les Malheurs de l'exactitude'', Paris, 1985. * Leonard Epp, [http://www.oxonianreview.org/wp/the-marquis-de-custine-and-the-question-of-russian-history/ 'The Marquis de Custine and the Question of Russian History'], review of Anka Muhlstein, ''Astolphe de Custine: The Last French Aristocrat'' and Astolphe de Custine, ''Letters from Russia'' in the ''[[Oxonian Review]]'' ==External links== * {{Gutenberg author | id=Custine,+Astolphe,+marquis+de}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Marquis de Custine}} * ''La Russie en 1839'': [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/25755 Volume I], [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/25850 Volume II], [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/27267 Volume III], [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/27345 Volume IV], (Gutenberg Project) * [http://www.nybooks.com/books/imprints/classics/letters-from-russia/ ''Letters from Russia''], edited by Anka Muhlstein (NYRB Classics, 2002) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Custine, Marquis De}} [[Category:1790 births]] [[Category:1857 deaths]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:LGBT writers from France]] [[Category:People from Moselle]] [[Category:Deaths from cerebrovascular disease]] [[Category:Western writers about Russia]] [[Category:LGBT novelists]] [[Category:LGBT poets]] [[Category:19th-century French novelists]] [[Category:French male poets]] [[Category:French Marquesses]] [[Category:LGBT Roman Catholics]] [[Category:19th-century French poets]] [[Category:Male novelists]] [[Category:19th-century French male writers]] [[Category:French-language LGBT writers]] [[Category:French male non-fiction writers]]

'''Maurice and Maralyn Bailey''' were a British couple who, in 1973, survived for 117 days on a rubber raft in the [[Pacific Ocean]] before being rescued.
Maralyn Bailey was born Maralyn Harrison on 24 April 1941 in [[Nottingham]], [[England]]. Maralyn and Maurice married in 1963.
==117 days adrift== The Baileys' journey began when they left [[Southampton]], England, in their {{convert|31|ft|m|adj=on}} [[yacht]] ''Auralyn.'' Their intended destination was [[New Zealand]]. They passed safely through the [[Panama Canal]] in February and were on their way to the [[Galapagos Islands]]. At dawn on 4 March 1973, their yacht was struck by a [[whale]] and severely damaged. After transferring some supplies to an inflated [[life raft]] and [[dinghy]] and salvaging some food, a [[compass]], and other supplies, the Baileys watched as ''Auralyn'' disappeared beneath the waves. To survive, they collected rainwater and when their meager food supplies ran out, began eating sea creatures such as [[turtle]]s, [[seabird]]s and fish caught by hand or with [[safety pin]]s fashioned into hooks. As they drifted in the open [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]], the couple saw seven different ships, but were unable to attract these ships' attention since their signal flares failed and their emergency kit did not contain a signalling mirror. Their life raft began to disintegrate and required frequent reinflation. They read and played card games early in their ordeal, but later the Baileys suffered terribly from malnutrition and friction-induced sores, the latter worsening due to the wet conditions in the raft. They encountered [[shark]]s and [[dolphin]]s and had to endure several severe storms.
After traveling some {{convert|1500|mi|km}}, the Baileys were rescued by the crew of the [[South Korea]]n [[fishing boat]] ''Weolmi 306'' on 30 June 1973. Sailors on the ship spotted the raft after initially passing it by. The couple was brought aboard in an emaciated state, having lost some {{convert|40|lb|kg}} apiece and with their legs barely able to support their weight. ''Weolmi 306'' brought them to [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] and to a fine welcome.
==Aftermath== The Baileys returned to England and wrote an account of their ordeal entitled ''117 Days Adrift'' (published with the title ''Staying Alive!'' in the [[United States]]), which was published in 1974 by [[Adlard Coles Nautical]]. The following year, they returned to the sea in their new yacht, ''Auralyn II.''
Maralyn Bailey died in 2002 at the age of 61. Maurice Bailey died in December 2017.
== External links == *[https://books.google.com/books/about/117_Days_Adrift.html?id=xJmFPwAACAAJ ''117 Days Adrift'' on Google Books] *[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/06/12/1023864298036.html Obituary for Maralyn Bailey from ''The Daily Telegraph'', London, June 13 2002]
==See also== * [[José Salvador Alvarenga]], survived 438 days adrift in the Pacific. * [[Steven Callahan]], survived 76 days adrift in the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]]. * [[Dougal Robertson]], survived 38 days adrift in the Pacific. * ''[[Rose Noelle]]'', [[trimaran]] on which four people survived 119 days adrift in the South Pacific. * [[Poon Lim]], who survived for 133 days adrift in the Atlantic. * [[Ambrogio Fogar]], survived 74 days adrift in the [[South Atlantic]] with Mauro Mancini (died 2 days after the rescue)

Burhanuddin.jpg | image_caption = delivering sermon during his [[Yemen]] visit in 2010 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|03|06|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Surat]], [[Gujarat]], [[British Raj]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|01|17|1915|03|06|df=y}} | death_place = [[Malabar Hill]], [[Mumbai]], [[India]] | death_cause = [[Cardiac arrest]]{{r|timesofindia.indiatimes.com}} | resting_place = [[Raudat Tahera]], Mumbai | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | organization = | style = His Holiness | home_town = | net_worth = | title = | term = 1965–2014 | predecessor = [[Syedna Taher Saifuddin]] | successor = [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]]{{cite news|author=The author has posted comments on this article |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/surat/2-5-lakh-Dawoodi-Bohras-arrival-boosts-business-in-Surat/articleshow/44945445.cms |title=2.5 lakh Dawoodi Bohras' arrival boosts business in Surat - The Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2014-10-27 |accessdate=2015-01-17}}{{cite web |url=http://freepressjournal.in/syedna-aali-qadr-mufaddal-saifuddin/ |title=Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin | Free Press Journal |publisher=Freepressjournal.in |date= |accessdate=2015-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140208175533/http://freepressjournal.in/syedna-aali-qadr-mufaddal-saifuddin/ |archivedate=8 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.asianage.com/mumbai/syedna-s-death-won-t-affect-succession-row-high-court-717 Succession suit currently led by Taher Fakhruddin] | boards = | spouse = Aaisaheba Amatullah | children = [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]], [[Qaidjoher Ezzuddin]] | parents = [[Taher Saifuddin]]

[[Husain Saifuddin]] {{small|(grand-son)}}
[[Taha Saifuddin]] {{small|(grand-son)}}
[[Khuzaima Qutbuddin|Khuzaima]] {{small|(half-brother)}}
[[Taher Fakhruddin|Taher]] {{small|(half-nephew)}} | awards = Star of Jordan, Padma Shri, Order of the Nile{{r|timesofindia.indiatimes.com}} | website = | module = | signature = Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin Signature.jpg | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = }} [[File:Mausoleum 51st and 52nd Dai.jpg|thumb|Mausoleum 51st and 52nd Dai]] [[File:Raudat tahera grave seen.JPG|thumb|grave seen from entrance Raudat Tahera ]] '''Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin''' (6 March 1915 – 17 January 2014){{Cite web|url=http://thedawoodibohras.com/details-page52.html|title=The Dawoodi Bohras - The 52nd al-Da`i al-Mutlaq|website=thedawoodibohras.com|access-date=2016-07-27}} was the 52nd [[Dā'ī al-Mutlaq]] of [[Dawoodi Bohras]], a subgroup within the [[Mustaali]], [[Ismaili]] [[Shia]] branch of Islam.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|publisher=}} He was appointed as the 52nd [[Dā'ī al-Mutlaq]] at the age of 52 in 1967.{{cite web|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html?page=4|accessdate=7 April 2014}} He was the longest living ''Dā'ī al-Mutlaq'' of the Dawoodi Bohra community.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html?page=2|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|publisher=}}{{cite web|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html|accessdate=7 April 2014}} Compared to those of his predecessor, Burhanuddin's policies were aimed at Islamization of his sect. Burhanuddin was presented the highest national civic honors by the leaders of Egypt and Jordan.{{cite news|title=18 killed in stampede in Mumbai ahead of spiritual leader Syedna's funeral|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/18-killed-in-stampede-in-Mumbai-ahead-of-spiritual-leader-Syednas-funeral/articleshow/29000436.cms|accessdate=7 April 2014 | work=The Times Of India}} He was the first Dā'ī al-Mutlaq to visit Europe and America.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html?page=8|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|publisher=}} ==Early life== Burhanuddin was born to [[Taher Saifuddin]] and Aaisaheba Husaina Aaisaheba in [[Surat]] in the Indian state of [[Gujarat]].{{cite book | first=Hozefa | last=Mohiyuddin | title=Tasbeeh al Mafakhir | publisher=Neelam Publication | year=2011}}{{vn|date=April 2014}}{{ISBN missing}}{{rp|16}} He was educated by his father, Taher Saifuddin.{{cite news|title=Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin: A symbol of piety, peace for Dawoodi Bohras|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-a-symbol-of-piety-peace-for-dawoodi-bohras/article5586815.ece|date=17 January 2014|work=The Hindu|location=Mumbai|accessdate=7 April 2014}} At the age of twelve, he survived a car accident in [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]], where his vehicle got hung on one wheel.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html?page=3|title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin|publisher=}} == Literary works == === Rasāʾil Ramaḍāniyya (Epistles) === The following are a list of Rasāʾil Ramaḍāniyya composed by Mohammed Burhanuddin . Each [[Risalah (fiqh)|Risalah]] is given a title gematrically equivalent to the [[Hijri]] year of its publication:{{Cite book|title=ميزة مفتاح خزائن العلوم|last=|first=|publisher=Aljamea-tus-Saifiyah, Badri Mahal|year=|isbn=|location=Mumbai, India.|pages=}}{{Cite journal|last=Traboulsi|first=Samer|year=2016|title=Transmission of Knowledge and Book Preservation in the Ṭayyibī Ismāʿīlī Tradition|url=|journal=Intellectual History of the Islamicate World|volume=|pages=|via=Brill}} {| class="wikitable sortable" !ID ! href="Mufaddal Saifuddin" |Title !Title (English) ! href="2014 Mumbai stampede" |[[Hijri]] !Pub.Year |- | href="Mufaddal Saifuddin" |SMB 00 | href="Khuzaima Qutbuddin" |حكمة الغيبة الحقيقية |Hikmat al-Ghaybah al-Haqiqiyyah |1385H | href="Mufaddal Saifuddin" | | href="Khuzaima Qutbuddin" | |- href="Mufaddal Saifuddin" | href="Dawoodi Bohra" |SMB 01 |استفتاح زبد المعارفIsteftah Zubad al-Ma'arif1385H |1386H |SMB 02فيوضات الجنةFuyoodhaat al-Jannah1386H |- |SMB 03 |سلام نضرة النعيم |Salaam Nadrah al-Na'eem |1387H | | |- |SMB 04 |ذات النور |Zaat al-Noor |1388H | | |- |SMB 05 |ظهور مجد الفاطميين |Zuhoor Majd al-Fatimiyeen |1389H | | |- |SMB 06بركة صبغة الله |Barakah Sibghah Allah |1390HSMB 07نشر الخير {{cite book|url=|title=نشر الخير (Nashr al-Khayr) 1391|last=His Holiness|first=Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin Saheb|date=1437H|publisher=His Holiness Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin Saheb, Badri Mahal, Mumbai, India|year=|isbn=|location=|page=|pages=}}Nashr al-Khayr1391H1437H2017 |-SMB 08 |SMB 08ندى الفيوضات {{cite book|url=|title=ندى الفيوضات ١٣٩٢|last=His Holiness|first=Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin Saheb|date=1438H|publisher=His Holiness Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin Saheb, Badri Mahal, Mumbai, India|isbn=|location=|page=}}Nadā al-Fūyūdāt1392H1438H |2018 |- |SMB 09 |سلسبيل روض القدس {{Cite book|title=سلسبيل روض القدر|last=His Holiness|first=Syedna Aali Qadr Mufaddal Saifuddin Saheb|publisher=Badri Mahal|year=1439H|isbn=|location=Mumbai, India|pages=}} |Salsabīl Rawd al-Quds |1392H |1439H |2019 |} == Activities == Burhanuddin issued a [[dress code]], calling for male Bohras to grow a beard and wear a white [[Gandhi cap|topi]] and [[kurta]], and for females to wear a colorful two piece [[abaya]]. This Islamization countered a trend toward assimilation into the larger ([[Hinduism|Hindu]]-oriented) culture of their neighbors that was prevalent under his predecessor, Taher Saifuddin.{{cite book |first=Jonah |last=Blank |title=Mullahs on the Mainframe: Islam and Modernity Among the Daudi Bohras |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2001 |pages=184–185 |isbn=0226056775}} In October 1999, Burhanuddin was elected Chancellor of the [[Aligarh Muslim University]],{{cite web|title=Signposts|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-elected-chancellor-of-aligarh-muslim-university/1/255159.html|work=India Today|date=18 October 1999|accessdate=7 April 2014}} a position that [[Taher Saifuddin#Da'i al-Mutlaq|his father also held]]. He is credited with expanding the two century old Arabic university [[Al Jamea tus Saifiyah]]. In 1983, a new campus of "Al Jamea tus Saifiyah" was built in Karachi by him.{{cite news|title=From Gurukul to IBO varsity|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/surat/From-Gurukul-to-IBO-varsity/articleshow/5204269.cms|first=Ashlesha|last=Khurana|date=6 November 2009|work=The Times of India|accessdate=7 April 2014}} He built "Burhaniyah Business Counselling Centre" in Mumbai to provide modern business solutions. He built ''[[Raudat Tahera]]'', a mausoleum of his father [[Taher Saifuddin]] in Mumbai, India. It is unique for its kind, having the entire [[Quran]] inscribed on its inner white walls in letters of gold and with precious stones.{{cite web | url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/latest-news-know-10-rare-facts-about-dawoodi-bohra-leader-syedna-32588.html?page=6 | title=Know 10 rare facts about Dawoodi Bohra leader Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin | accessdate=7 April 2014 | work=India TV | page=6 | date=12 February 2014}} It was inaugurated in 1975 by the erstwhile President of India [[Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed]]. In 1998, he constructed the [[Mahad al-Zahra]] institute for memorization and recitation of the [[Quran]]. Mohammed Burhanuddin is credited with the establishment of community kitchens to provide meals everyday to the [[Dawoodi Bohra]] families, thus providing free time for women to pursue economic, educational or religious activities.{{cite news|title=City Bohris start dabba service for community households|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/mumbai/city-bohris-start-dabba-service-for-community-households/article1-746239.aspx|work=Hindustan Times|first=Reetika|last=Subramanian|date=16 September 2011|location=Mumbai|accessdate=11 July 2015}}{{cite news|title=Faith and food in the Bohra way|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2301221/FORTUNE-COOKIE-Faith-food-Bohra-way.html|work=Mail Online India|date=29 March 2013|first=Sourish|last=Bhattacharyya|accessdate=11 July 2015|location=London}} The community kitchens don't discriminate between the privileged and the underprivileged sections, both getting the same "good quality and hygienically-prepared" food,{{cite news|title=Bohra women get respite from cooking|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-bohra-women-get-respite-from-cooking-1659990|work=DNA|location=Mumbai|first=Shabana|last=Ansari|date=9 March 2012|accessdate=7 July 2015}} while the community members have the provision of paying for their own family, and for sponsoring those who cannot afford it.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/aurangabad/Freedom-from-the-kitchen-smoke-heat/articleshow/47942733.cms|accessdate=7 July 2015|title=Freedom from the kitchen smoke & heat|work=The Times of India|location=Aurangabad|first=Ranjana|last=Diggikar|date=5 July 2015}} Mohammad Burhanuddin is also credited with conceptualizing and establishing [[Saifee Hospital]] in Mumbai. The hospital is a state-of-the-art, multi-specialty, 250-bed hospital dedicated to providing modern medical care.{{cite news|title=saifee hospital mumbai|url=http://wecareindia.com/saifee-hospital-mumbai/|work=Best Hospitals in India Low Cost Treatment {{!}} Cost Treatment in India at Best Hospitals}} It was inaugurated in 2005 by [[Dr. Manmohan Singh]], the erstwhile prime minister of India.{{cite news|title=Indian Prime Minister inaugurates Saifee Hospital in Mumbai|url=http://wam.ae/en/details/1395227441320|work=wam}} ===Ashara Mubaraka=== The following are the venues where Mohammed Burhanuddin has performed Ashara Mubaraka: {{cn|date=March 2018}} * 1435AH/2013AD-Mumbai,{{flag|India}}; 1434/2012-Surat, [[India]]; 1433/2011-Mumbai, [[India]]; Hijra 1432/2010-Mumbai, [[India]] * 1431/2009–Marol, Mumbai,{{flag|India}}; 1430/2008–Mombasa,{{flag|Kenya}};1429/2008–Colombo,{{flag|Sri Lanka}} * 1428/2007–Colombo, {{flag|Sri Lanka}}; 1427/2006 – Mumbai, {{flag|India}} [Saify Mahal]; Hijra 1426 / 2005 – Surat, India * 1425/2004– Dubai, [[U.A.E.]]; 1424/2003 – Mumbai; {{flag|India}} [Saify Masjid]; Hijra 1423 / 2002 – Indore, India * 1422/2001– Houston, {{flag|U.S.A.}}; 1421/2000–Surat, {{flag|India}}; 1420/1999 – Colombo, {{flag|Sri Lanka}}. * 1419/1998– Nairobi, {{flag|Kenya}}; Hijra 1418 / 1997 – Surat, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1417 / 1996 – Karachi, {{flag|Pakistan}} * 1416/1995– Mombasa, {{flag|Kenya}}; Hijra 1415 / 1994 – Mumbai, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1414 / 1993 – Mombasa, {{flag|Kenya}} * 1413/1992– Pune, {{flag|India}}; 1412 / 1991–Colombo, {{flag|Sri Lanka}}; 1411 / 1990 – Dar es Salaam, {{flag|Tanzania}} * 1410/1989– Surat, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1409 / 1988 – Mumbai, India; Hijra 1408 / 1987 – Karachi, {{flag|Pakistan}} * 1407/1986– Indore, India; Hijra 1406 / 1985 – Surat, India{{flag|India}}; Hijra 1405 / 1984 – Nairobi, {{flag|Kenya}} * 1404/1983– Karachi; {{flag|Pakistan}}; Hijra 1403 / 1982 – Sidhpur, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1402 / 1981 – Cairo, {{flag|Egypt}} * 1401/1980- Cairo, {{flag|Egypt}}; Hijra 1400 / 1979 – Mumbai, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1399 / 1978 – Jamnagar, India * 1398/1977– Karachi, {{flag|Pakistan}}; Hijra 1397 / 1976 – Madras, India; Hijra 1396 / 1976 – Kolkata, {{flag|India}} * 1395/1975– Mumbai, India; Hijra 1394 / 1974 – Mumbai, India; Hijra 1393 / 1973 – Mumbai, {{flag|India}} * 1392/1972– Surat, India; Hijra 1391 / 1971 – Kolkata, {{flag|India}}; Hijra 1390 / 1970 – Colombo, {{flag|Sri Lanka}} * 1389/1969– Mecca, {{flag|Saudi Arabia}}; Hijra 1388 / 1968 – Mumbai, India; Hijra 1387 / 1967 – Mumbai, {{flag|India}} * 1386/1966- Mumbai, {{flag|India}} ==Awards and honours== * "[[Order of the Star of Jordan]]", the highest civic honour of Jordan by the King of Jordan.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Bohras-protest-Syednas-half-brothers-claim/articleshow/29391867.cms|title=Bohras protest Syedna's half-brother 's claim|work=The Times Of India|accessdate=26 March 2014}} * "[[Order of the Nile]]", the highest civilian honour of Egypt.{{cite news|title=Leader of Bohra community Dr Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin dead at 102 - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/660017/leader-of-bohra-community-dr-syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-dead-at-102/|work=The Express Tribune|date=17 January 2014}} * "Honorary Doctrates", by Al-Azhar University, Egypt, Aligarh Muslim University, India and University of Karachi, Pakistan. * On 6 March 2011, Burhani Foundation, India made largest distribution of bird feeders (20,631) to celebrate Mohammed Buranuddin 100th birthday (according to the Islamic calendar). It was recorded in [[Guinness World Records]].{{cite web|title=Largest distribution of bird feeders|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/9000/largest-distribution-of-bird-feeders|accessdate=7 April 2014}}{{cite web|title=Mohammed Dilawar’s ‘save sparrows’ campaign enters Guinness record|url=http://www.theweekendleader.com/Success/534/Honourable-work.html|accessdate=7 April 2014}} * [[Padma Shri]], the fourth highest civilian award of India, in 2015.{{cite web|title=Padma Awards 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VrWjEuo3?url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=114952|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=114952|publisher=Press Information Bureau|accessdate=25 January 2015|archivedate=26 January 2015|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} * Mohammed Burhanuddin was named one of [[The 500 Most Influential Muslims]] in the years 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012 & 2013.{{cite web|url=http://themuslim500.com/download|title=The Muslim 500|publisher=}} == Death == Burhanuddin died of cardiac attack at his home Saifee Mahal in Mumbai on 17 January 2014. The Bohra community announced a 40-day mourning period in respect of the departed leader.{{cite web|title=Dawoodi Bohra community spiritual head, Dr Burhanuddin passes away|url=http://archive.mid-day.com/news/2014/jan/170114-dawoodi-bohra-community-spiritual-head-dr-syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-passes-away-mumbai.htm|accessdate=7 April 2014}} He was buried at Raudat Tahera Mausoleum in Bhendi Bazar, Mumbai beside his father Taher Saifuddin.{{cite web|title=Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin laid to rest in Mumbai, 70,000+ mourners attend funeral|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/maharashtra/syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-laid-to-rest-in-mumbai-70-000-mourners-attend-funeral_904988.html|accessdate=7 April 2014}} His second son [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]] led the "Namaz-e-Janaza" (funeral procession) of his father at the Saifee Mosque. Half mast of Flag and state honor was given by Indian Government during his funeral.{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/maharashtra/syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-laid-to-rest-in-mumbai-70000-mourners-attend-funeral_904988.html|title=Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin laid to rest in Mumbai, 70,000 mourners attend funeral|work=Zee News}} The day after his death, a crowd of supporters assembled outside his residence to pay their respects; when the gates were opened to let them in, a [[2014 Mumbai stampede|human stampede]] ensued, killing eighteen people.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-25790752 |title=Funeral stampede kills 18 in Indian city of Mumbai |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2014-01-18 |accessdate=2014-06-12}} A commemoration service held one year after Burhanuddin's death drew an estimated three lakh people to Mumbai; two townships were built specially to accommodate them.{{cite news |newspaper=DNA India |title=Dawoodi Bohras observe late Syedna's death anniversay |date=5 January 2015 |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-dawoodi-bohras-observe-late-syedna-s-death-anniversay-2049655}} ==Succession== {{Family tree Moulai Tarmal/Bharmal to Syedna Burhanuddin}} {{main|53rd Syedna succession controversy (Dawoodi Bohra)}} Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin, died in January 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/660017/leader-of-bohra-community-dr-syedna-mohammed-burhanuddin-dead-at-102/|title=Leader of Bohra community Dr Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin dead at 102|last=|first=|date=|website=The Express Tribune|publisher=|access-date=}} As per the tenets of the sect{{cite book|url=|title=Mullahs on the Mainframe : Islam and Modernity Among the Daudi Bohras|last=Blank|first=Jonah|date=2001|publisher=University of Chicago Press; 1 edition (15 April 2001)|isbn=978-0-226-05676-0|location=|page=135 & 165}} each predecessor is required to nominate his successor prior to his death.{{cite book|url=|title=The Isma'ilis: Their History and Doctrines|last=Daftary|first=Farhad|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=1-139-46578-3|location=|page=275}}{{cite book|url=|title=A Modern History of the Ismailis: Continuity and Change in a Muslim Community|last=Daftary|first=Farhad|date=2011|publisher=I. B. Tauris|isbn=1-84511-717-4|location=|page=333}} His death sparked a succession crisis where two rival claimants emerged for the title of 53rd Dā'ī al-Mutlaq:{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rizwan-mawani/the-intricacies-of-succes_b_4687546.html|title=The Intricacies of Succession: Two Claimants Emerge for Dawoodi Bohra Leadership|last=Mawani|first=Rizwan|date=30 January 2014|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=11 February 2014}} his son, [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]], and his half-brother, [[Khuzaima Qutbuddin]], who was previously ''Mazoon'' {{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=r_FExBRnC3YC&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163|title=Mullahs on the Mainframe: Islam and Modernity Among the Daudi Bohras|last=Blank|first=Jonah|date=2001|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|isbn=0-226-05676-7|location=|page=163}} of the Dawoodi Bohra.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/mumbai/talk-of-rift-among-bohras-over-syedna-s-successor/article1-1044475.aspx|title=Talk of rift among Bohras over Syedna's successor|date=15 April 2013|newspaper=Hindustan Times|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326095043/http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/mumbai/talk-of-rift-among-bohras-over-syedna-s-successor/article1-1044475.aspx|archivedate=26 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} The challenge created a divide in the community with the vast majority aligning with [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]]{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2014-01-29/pune/46781344_1_pune-cantonment-peace-march-dawoodi-bohras|title=Dawoodi Bohras stage a peace march|date=|work=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-bohras-make-anti-syedna-faction-s-ex-communication-official-stick-by-mufaddal-saifuddin-1958375|title=Bohras make anti-Syedna faction's ex-communication official, stick by Mufaddal Saifuddin|date=|work=}} whilst a small number aligned with [[Khuzaima Qutbuddin]].{{cite Breakaway Dawoodi Bohra faction alleges harassment|date=|work=}} [[Mufaddal Saifuddin]] assumed control of the [[Dawoodi Bohra]] administration and infrastructure. {{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{MedalTableTop|sport= Women's athletics|country_code=KEN|medals= {{Medal|Competition|[[IAAF World Half Marathon Championships]]}} {{Medal|Bronze |[[2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships|2012 Kavarna]]|Half marathon}} {{Medal|Silver |[[2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships|2012 Kavarna]]|Team}} }} '''Paskalia Chepkorir Kipkoech''' (also known as ''Pasalia Jepkorir''; born 22 December 1988) is a Kenyan [[long-distance runner]] who competes mainly in [[half marathon]] races. Her personal best of 67:17 minutes ranks her within the top twenty all-time for the distance. She was the bronze medallist at the [[2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships]].
She won a [[3000 metres]] silver medal at the [[2003 World Youth Championships in Athletics]] at the age of fourteen. She moved up to the half marathon distance in 2008 and has won races including the [[Berlin Half Marathon]], [[Nairobi Half Marathon]], [[Udine Half Marathon]] and the [[Corrida Internacional de São Silvestre]]. She also features in the top ten all-time for the [[10K run]], with a best of 30:57 minutes.
==Career== ===Early career=== Raised in [[Molo, Kenya]], she is from the [[Kipsigis people|Kipsigis tribe]] originating from the west of Kenya.<ref>Njenga, Peter (20 June 2003). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/kenyan-youths-biographies Kenyan Youths Biographies]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She came to prominence in 2003 when, after a fifth place performance in the [[5000 metres]] in a senior meeting in [[Eldoret]],<ref>Njenga, Peter (11 May 2003). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/youngsters-spring-surprises-in-eldoret Youngsters spring surprises in Eldoret]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> she was chosen to represent Kenya at the [[2003 World Youth Championships in Athletics]].<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/kenya-announces-team-for-world-youths Kenya announces team for World Youths]. IAAF (18 June 2003). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref>
The fourteen-year-old went on to take the silver medal in the [[3000 metres]] behind Morocco's [[Siham Hilali]] (two years her senior).<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/wy.htm World Youth Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/3rd-iaaf-world-youth-championships-opens-with 3rd IAAF World Youth Championships opens with gold for Morocco]. IAAF (9 July 2003). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> Chepkorir was the youngest competitor at the tournament.<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/age-matters-in-sherbrooke Age matters in Sherbrooke]. IAAF (10 July 2003). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She attempted to qualify for the [[2005 World Youth Championships in Athletics]], but finished eighth at the national youth championships.<ref>Okoth, Omulo (16 June 2005). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/world-junior-cross-country-silver-medallist-r World junior cross country silver medallist races into the Kenyan team for Marrakech ]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref>
===First senior races=== A small runner, only reaching {{height|m=1.42}},<ref name=NY>Biscayart, Eduardo (1 January 2010). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/kwambai-and-kipkoech-take-sao-paulo-new-years Kwambai and Kipkoech take Sao Paulo New Year's Eve wins]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> Chepkorir started to compete at meetings abroad in 2007, running in Spain. She made her debut in the [[half marathon]] the following year, beginning with the [[Lisbon Half Marathon]] where she ran 71:15 minutes for eighth place. She was victorious at the [[Media Maraton de Ribarroja]] and also the half-section of the [[Nairobi Marathon]] that year.<ref name=Tilas>[http://www.tilastopaja.org/db/atw.php?ID=28221&Season=2007&Odd=0 Paskalia Chepkorir]. Tilastopaja. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> Her national performances also improved, as she was runner-up to [[Peninah Jepchumba]] in the 5000 m at the [[Kenyan Athletics Championships]] and was in the top two at multiple meets on the [[Athletics Kenya Cross Country Series]].<ref>Njenga, Peter (28 June 2008). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/800m-marvel-jelimo-comes-second-at-400-keny 800m marvel Jelimo comes second at 400 – Kenyan Champs, Day 3]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/korikwiang-and-kamakya-steal-limelight-in-mac Korikwiang and Kamakya steal limelight in Machakos – AK XC Series, Meet 1]. IAAF (8 November 2008). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/soi-and-chepkorir-prevail-cherono-unchallenge Soi and Chepkorir prevail; Cherono unchallenged in junior race – AK XC, Meet 2]. IAAF (15 November 2008). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref>
A sixth place finish at the [[Kenyan Cross Country Championships]] put her in the frame for the national team at the [[2009 IAAF World Cross Country Championships]], but the selectors opted for [[Pauline Korikwiang]] instead, who was in good form that season but performed poorly at the event.<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/veterans-mosop-and-kiplagat-prevail-in-nairob Veterans Mosop and Kiplagat prevail in Nairobi – Kenyan World XC Champs Trials]. IAAF (21 February 2009). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> Chepkorir ran extensively on the roads that year, with highlights including a [[10K run|10K]] win in [[Brescia]],<ref>Sampaolo, Diego (15 March 2009). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/chebois-210-tops-out-results-in-brescia Cheboi's 2:10 tops out results in Brescia ]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> a defence of her Ribarroja title, a personal best time of 69:56 minutes for third at the [[Prague Half Marathon]],<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/course-records-fall-in-prague-prague-half-m Course records fall in Prague – Prague Half Marathon report]. IAAF (28 March 2009). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> a win at the [[Udine Half Marathon]], and a third place at the [[Porto Half Marathon]].<ref>Fernandes, António Manuel (18 October 2009). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/gebrselassie-just-outside-60-minutes-at-porto Gebrselassie just outside 60 minutes at Porto Half – UPDATED]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She was also the 5000 m runner-up at the Kenyan nationals that year.<ref name=Tilas/> She closed the year with a win at the [[Corrida Internacional de São Silvestre]] 15K.<ref name=NY/>
===Elite half marathons=== Chepkorir established herself among the top half marathon runners in the world with a win at the [[Berlin Half Marathon]] in March 2010, running a personal best of 69:43 minutes to beat [[Eunice Kales]].<ref>Wenig, Jörg (28 March 2010). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/wondimu-ends-kenyan-streak-kipkoech-takes-wom Wondimu ends Kenyan streak, Kipkoech takes women's race in Berlin – UPDATED]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She returned to the German city for the [[BIG 25 Berlin]] race, and placed third.<ref>Wenig, Jörg (9 May 2010). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/kosgei-keitany-shatter-25km-world-records-in Kosgei, Keitany shatter 25Km World records in Berlin – Updated]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She was selected to compete for Kenya at the [[2010 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships]] but injury curtailed her season before she could make her international senior debut there.<ref name=Tilas/><ref>Ramsak, Bob (13 September 2010). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/kiplagat-and-kiprop-lead-kenyan-squad-for-nan Kiplagat and Kiprop lead Kenyan squad for Nanning – IAAF / Sinopec World Half-Marathon Championships]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref>
She missed the 2011 season but re-emerged in 2012 to set some personal bests in Brazil, running 30:57 minutes for the 10K and 67:17 minutes at the [[Rio de Janeiro Half Marathon]]. Both marks moved her up into the top twenty all-time runners for each event and ranked her in the top five globally that season.<ref name=Tilas/><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/records/toplists/road-running/10-kilometres/outdoor/women/senior 10 Kilometres – women – senior – outdoor]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/records/toplists/road-running/half-marathon/outdoor/women/senior Half Marathon – women – senior – outdoor]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She entered the [[2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships]] as one of Kenyan's quickest runners and she ran at the front of the race, eventually reducing the leaders down to herself [[Meseret Hailu]] and [[Feyse Tadese]]. She fell back in the latter stages of the race and finished with the [[bronze medal]], ten seconds behind the winner.<ref>Ramsak, Bob (6 October 2012). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/hailu-surprises-in-kavarna-womens-race-repo Hailu surprises in Kavarna – World Half Marathon Championships]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She also led the Kenyan team to the silver medals in the team competition.<ref>[http://dt9guucc6nuua.cloudfront.net/competitiondocuments/pdf/4862/AT-HMAR-W-F--1--.ST1.pdf IAAF World Half Marathon Championships – Kavarna (BUL) – 6 October 2012 – Team Standings – Half Marathon Women]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> This competition marked her only defeat of the year when her final race at the Nairobi Half Marathon resulted in her sixth win of the year.<ref name=Tilas/><ref>Mutuota, Mutwiri (28 October 2012). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/kibet-breaks-nairobi-marathon-record Kibet breaks Nairobi Marathon record]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref>
Her winning streak was abruptly ended in 2013 – a year in which she won no major races.<ref name=Tilas/> Her best race came in February at the [[RAK Half Marathon]], although her time of 68:08 minutes was only enough for eighth in the top quality contest.<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/kabuu-and-kipsang-triumph-in-high-quality-rac Kabuu and Kamworor triumph in high-quality races at Ras al-Khaimah Half]. IAAF (15 February 2013). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> The remaining highlights of that year for Chepkorir were third placings at the [[Carlsbad 5000]] and the Lisbon Half Marathon,<ref>Fernandes, António Manuel (24 March 2013). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/a-lonely-koech-and-a-smart-kiplagat-take-vict A lonely Koech and a smart Kiplagat take victory in Lisbon]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/third-win-in-a-row-for-gebremeskel-burka-make Third win in a row for Gebremeskel, Burka makes Ethiopian double in Carlsbad]. IAAF (8 April 2013). Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> as well as a close runner-up finish to [[Sylvia Kibet]] at the [[Carrera de la Mujer]].<ref>Biscayart, Eduardo (29 September 2013). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/sylvia-kibets-sprint-finish-helps-her-triumph Kibet's sprint finish helps her triumph at Bogota's Carrera de la Mujer"]. IAAF. Retrieved on 20 October 2014.</ref> She missed the 2014 season.<ref name=Tilas/>

[[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F051673-0059, Adolf Hitler und Eva Braun auf dem Berghof.jpg|thumb|[[Adolf Hitler]] with [[Eva Braun]] and their dogs at the [[Berghof (residence)|Berghof]], [[Bavaria]] in June 1942.]] The possibility that [[Adolf Hitler]] had [[monorchism|only one testicle]] has been a fringe subject among historians and academics researching the German leader. The rumour may be an [[urban myth]], possibly originating from the contemporary British [[military song]] "[[Hitler Has Only Got One Ball]]". Nevertheless, research, eyewitness testimony and historical study have not been able to prove or disprove the suggestion.
Hitler's doctor {{Interlanguage link multi|Erwin Giesing|de}} and his personal physician [[Theodor Morell]] disregarded the idea of Hitler's monorchism and said there was nothing wrong with Hitler's testicles.<ref>Waite, Robert G.L. ''The Psychopathic God: Adolf Hitler'', Basic Books, N.Y.C., 1977, pp. 150–152</ref> In December 2015, it was reported that doctor's notes from [[Landsberg Prison]] recorded that Hitler had "right-sided [[cryptorchidism]]".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/19/hitler-really-did-have-only-one-testicle-german-researcher-claims Hitler really did have only one testicle, German researcher claims] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 19 December 2015</ref>
==Evidence==
===World War I medical records=== In November 2008, the discovery of an eye-witness account on how Hitler was treated after being shot on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] during [[World War I]] was announced in the press. According to these reports, a former German Army Medic named Johan Jambor gave an account to a Polish priest and amateur historian, Franciszek Pawlar, in the 1960s, of how he saved Hitler's life in 1916 after a groin injury and saw that he had lost a testicle.<ref name="fox"/> Jambor said that as they were carrying Hitler away, they came under French fire and had to temporarily abandon him, upon which he began to scream very loudly, imploring them to come back and threatening them with [[court martial]] if they left him behind.<ref name="bild"/> Pawlar's record of the conversation was discovered by Pawlar's relatives and published by Polish author Grzegorz Wawoczny.<ref name="fox">[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,454744,00.html German Medic's Account Confirms Hitler Had Only One Testicle] ''Fox News'' 19 November 2008</ref> According to the British tabloid ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|Sun]]'', a surviving friend of Jambor's, Blassius Hanczuch, has confirmed the story, adding that Jambor and his co-rescuers dubbed Hitler "screamer".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hitler HAD only got one ball|url = http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/1945960/Hitler-HAD-only-got-one-ball.html|website = www.thesun.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-27|date = 2008-11-20}}</ref> Tabloid Bild says that according to Jambor, "His abdomen and legs were covered in blood. Hitler was wounded in the abdomen and had lost a testicle. His first question to the doctor was: 'Can I still father children?{{'"}}<ref name="bild">[http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/vermischtes/2008/11/19/lebensretter-von-adolf-hitler/lebte-in-angst-weil-er-von-hodenverletzung-wusste.html "Weil er von der peinlichen Hodenverletzung wusste: Hitlers Lebensretter lebte Jahrzehnte in Angst"], ''Bild'', 19 November 2008 {{de icon}} "Sein Unterleib und seine Beine waren voller Blut. Hitler war am Unterleib verletzt und hatte einen Hoden verloren. Seine erste Frage an den Arzt war: 'Kann ich noch Kinder zeugen?"</ref>
Military records show that Hitler was wounded in 1916 during the [[Battle of the Somme]], which has been described as a wound to the groin or in the left thigh when a shell exploded in the dispatch runners' dugout.{{sfn|Kershaw|2008|p=57}} Other more recent historians, such as [[Ian Kershaw]], conclude the wound was to Hitler's left thigh.{{sfn|Kershaw|2008|p=57}}
===Prison records===
In December 2015, it was reported that documents from Landsberg prison were to be released and compiled for a book. Amongst them is a note in prison doctor Josef Brinsteiner's "Aufnahmebuch" (book of arrivals at prison), who reportedly examined Hitler in 1923, saying that he had "right-sided [[cryptorchidism]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/geschichte/zweiter-weltkrieg/article150109063/Der-wahre-Grund-fuer-Hitlers-gestoertes-Sexleben.html|title=Adolf Hitler litt unter angeborener Missbildung an seinen Hoden - DIE WELT|author=Sven Felix Kellerhoff|date=18 December 2015|work=DIE WELT}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.de/20151218/hitler-really-did-have-just-one-ball-professor|title=Hitler really did have just one ball: historian|author=|date=|work=thelocal.de}}</ref>
===Soviet autopsy=== In 1970, the [[Death of Adolf Hitler|Soviet autopsy]] on Hitler's remains was released. This document, which was allegedly compiled shortly after the conclusion of [[World War II]] on the basis of the examination of the remains claimed to be those of the [[Führer]], stated he was [[monorchid]]. It stated:
{{quote|The autopsy performed by the Red Army pathologists on Hitler's body... [produced clear] findings:
The left testicle could not be found either in the scrotum or on the spermatic cord inside the inguinal canal, or in the small pelvis[...]}}
[[Robert G. L. Waite]], in his book ''[[The Psychopathic God: Adolf Hitler]]'' (1978), accepted the accuracy of this evidence:
{{quote|Since the matter is of considerable importance to the psychological development of Hitler from infancy onward, let us pause here and come to grips with the problem of the Fuehrer's testicles. It can now be affirmed that the British [[Tommy Atkins|Tommies]] were right all along in the first line of their version of the Colonel Bogey March, they were although manifestly mistaken in the last—that is to say, unless [[Goebbels children|Goebbels' six children]] were the progeny of adoption, paternal surrogacy or some hitherto unconsidered, presumably unpalatable "[[Gott mit uns]]" form of divine intervention.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tNaS6C5os8kC&pg=PA150&dq=let+us+pause+here+and+come+to+grips+with+the+problem+of+the+Fuehrer%27s+testicles |title=The Psychopathic God: Adolf Hitler - Robert G. L. Waite - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-25}}</ref><ref name=Waite150>{{cite book|last1=Waite|first1=Robert G.L.|title=The psychopathic god : Adolf Hitler|date=1993|publisher=Da Capo Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0306805141|pages=150–152|edition=Da Capo Press paperback ed., Unabr. republication of the ed. first publ. in New York, Basic Books, in 1977 / with the add. of a new foreword by the author and some emendations}}</ref>}}
Because the release occurred at the height of the [[Cold War]], its conclusions have been questioned in terms of [[propaganda]]. Journalist [[Ron Rosenbaum]] argues in his book ''[[Explaining Hitler]]'' that the Soviet autopsy of Hitler cannot be accepted as authoritative because the Führer's body was said to have been almost completely [[Cremation|immolated]] after his suicide inside the ''[[Führerbunker]]''. There were insufficient remains for any proper analysis to be conducted. Rosenbaum suggests that based on information from Hitler's own doctor and recantations by the compilers of the published form of the report, the Soviet autopsy report was a fabrication. Noted historian [[Ian Kershaw]] describes the corpses of [[Eva Braun]] and Hitler as being fully burned when the Red Army found them, with only a lower jaw with dental work identifiable as Hitler's remains.<ref>Kershaw, Ian (2008). ''Hitler: A Biography'', p. 958.</ref>
An interview with the Soviet doctor, Lt. Col. [[Favst Shkaravsky]], who led Hitler's autopsy is in the extras section on the DVD of the 1970s documentary series ''[[The World At War]]''. Shkaravsky claims that those performing the autopsy unexpectedly found one testicle missing. Shkaravsky states categorically that Hitler was not shot in the head. Although since the filming of the series, the evidence has been found showing that Hitler [[Death of Adolf Hitler#Suicide|shot himself in the right temple]], and it has been shown that different versions of Hitler's fate were presented by the Soviet Union according to its political desires.<ref>Eberle, Henrik & Uhl Matthias (2005). ''The Hitler Book: The Secret Dossier Prepared for Stalin from the Interrogations of Hitler's Personal Aides'', p. 288.</ref><ref>Kershaw, Ian (2008). ''Hitler: A Biography'', p. 955.</ref>
==Song== During [[World War II]], the song "[[Hitler Has Only Got One Ball]]" was popular among [[United Kingdom|British]] citizens. British author [[Donough O'Brien (author)|Donough O'Brien]] says his father, [[Toby O'Brien]], wrote an original set of lyrics in August 1939 as part of the country's official program of [[propaganda]].<ref>Donough O'Brien, [http://www.fringe-benefits.co.uk/frinfacs.html Fringe Facts], 2000, [https://web.archive.org/web/20010314042458/http://www.fringe-benefits.co.uk/frinfacs.html archived] at the [[Wayback Machine]], 14 March 2001.</ref> This has led to the suspicion that the source of this myth stems from the British song, usually put to the tune of the [[Colonel Bogey March]].
==Modern allusions== Before finding success with [[Violent Femmes]] in the 1980s, band members [[Brian Ritchie]] and [[Victor DeLorenzo]] were members of a group called "Hitler's Missing Testis".<ref>{{cite web|last=Rozen |first=Leah |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20094323,00.html |title=No, the Violent Femmes Aren't Lady Wrestlers, but They've Got Young Rock Fans in Their Grip |publisher=People.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> During the 1980s, the [[Brisbane]] [[anarcho-punk]] scene included the band "Hitler's Other Testicle". They regularly played songs on the subject of Hitler's possible monorchism, including "Where Did It Go?" and "The Sadness of Autumn".

{{Infobox person | name = Sister María Justa de Jesús | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = María Justa | birth_date = January 6, 1667 | birth_place = [[La Victoria de Acentejo]], [[Tenerife]] | death_date = 1723 | death_place = [[La Orotava]], Tenerife | nationality = Spanish | other_names = | occupation = [[Nun]] and [[mysticism|mystic]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''María Justa de Jesús''' (January 6, 1667 - 1723) was a Spanish [[Franciscans|Franciscan]] [[nun]] and [[mysticism|mystic]].
== Early life == She was born in La Victoria de Acentejo in the north of the island of [[Tenerife]]. She trained as a Franciscan in the Saint Joseph Convent in [[La Orotava]]. Her life was involved in mysticism and controversy.<ref name=A>[http://diariodeavisos.elespanol.com/2017/03/galeria-misticos-tinerfenos/ Los 4 místicos tinerfeños]</ref>
== Career == The [[Holy Inquisition]] tried her as a [[witch]].<ref name="A" /> She was accused of practicing [[Molinist]] doctrines.<ref name="B">[https://www.academia.edu/18989443/Los_conventos_de_La_Orotava Los conventos de La Orotava. Manuel Hernández González.]</ref> It was hinted that the relationship with her confessor was not appropriate for a religious person.<ref name="A" /> Her biographer and confessor, Andrés de Abreu, burned the biography he had written about her.<ref>[https://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/3361096.pdf Alrededor de Fray de Abreu (1647-1725): Historiografía literaria y una obra inédita.]</ref>
However, [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] friar Jose Herrera said that among her virtues was to give sight to the blind, to make the deaf hear, the mute to speak, heal the lame, heal diseases and expel [[demons]].<ref name="A" />
Sr. Maria Justa healed the sick by transferring to her person the evils and diseases that afflicted them. [[Shamanic]] priests<ref name="A" /> in other cultures used analogous techniques to cure convalescents. That similarity fed the suspicions of those who called her an "''[[Alumbrados|alumbrada]]''". During these healings, the nun suffered multiple ailments, covering her body in sores and elevating her body temperature, which brought her to the brink of death.
== Death == Sister Maria Justa died in 1723. According to the chronicles of the time her body showed signs of sanctity, such as flexibility, pleasant fragrances and fluidity of her blood.<ref name="A" /> After her death the Franciscan Order in the [[Canary Islands]] conducted a process of [[canonization]] that was later halted.<ref name="B" />
== ''Alumbrados'' == Her case was ascribed to the phenomenon of the ''"[[Alumbrados]]"'' that arose in small Castilian towns two centuries earlier. These were people who professed doctrines considered heretical by the [[Catholic Church]], believing that union with [[God]] came only through mystical experiences and private prayer, without intermediation of the [[sacraments]]..

{{flagicon image|Flag of al-Qaeda.svg|size=23px}} [[Al-Qaeda]]
(2006-2007) *{{flagicon image|ShababFlag.svg|size=23px}} [[al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb|AQIM]]
(2006-2007) |serviceyears = 1994-2007 |rank = [[Emir]] of central [[Maghreb]] for Al-Qaeda and deputy of [[Abdelmalek Droukdel]] |battles = [[Algerian Civil War]] *[[11 April 2007 Algiers bombings]] [[Insurgency in the Maghreb (2002–present)|Insurgency in the Maghreb]] *[[Operation Enduring Freedom – Trans Sahara]] }} }} '''Sofiane el-Fassila''' ({{lang-ar|سفيان الفصيلة}}), also known as '''Harek Zoheir''' حارك زهير, (born 1975 – October 6, 2007) served as the second-in-command of [[Al Qaeda]] in [[North Africa]] until [[Algeria]]n security forces killed him.[http://www.dailycomet.com/article/20071010/API/710100566 A Top Algeria Al-Qaida Affiliate Killed] Daily Comet[http://www.pr-inside.com/reports-top-al-qaida-in-islamic-north-r238922.htm Reports: Top al-Qaida in Islamic North Africa leader killed by Algerian security forces] PR-Inside ==Life and militant activity== Sofiane born in 1975 in Sidi Daoud in the region of Dellys, and he became a militant in the Algerian jihadist group [[Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat]] in 1994.http://www.djazairess.com/fr/liberte/82829 In 2006, he was appointed by [[Abdelmalek Droukdel]] as the head of central zone of AQIM's operating space. The following year, following the Droukdel's oath of allegiance to [[al-Qaeda]] dubbing of Droukdel to the rank of "[[emir]]" of al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, Sofiane became one of his closest commanders. Involved in numerous terrorist attacks, Sofiane was known to be the head of a network specialized in arms trafficking, a cell of which was dismantled in [[Berriane]] in 2006.http://www.vitaminedz.org/tribunal-criminel-de-boumerdes/Articles_15688_162626_35_1.html Sofiane was presented as the brain of the attacks of 11 April 2007 in Algiers, perpetrated against the Government Palace in the heart of the capital. However, some sources agree that the real coordinator of the attacks was Sid Ali Rachid, also known as Ali Dix, presented as the "military advisor" of Droukdel.http://www.vitaminedz.org/-ali-dix-tombe-dans-une-embuscade-au-djurdjura/Articles_15688_29802_0_1.html In June 2007, the Court of Boumerdès sentenced him in absentia to 20 years imprisonment and then to life imprisonment for several cases of terrorism. Harek Zoheir died on 6 October 2007, killed in a counter-terrorism operation by the Algerian security forces in the Boghni region of Kabylia. Two other fighters are also killed during the operation.http://equoter.blogspot.gr/2007/10/algeria-oil-islam-war-on-terror.htmlhttp://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2007-10-10-1217438287_x.htm ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.adl.org/terrorism/symbols/al_qaeda_maghreb.asp Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) (INTERNATIONAL TERRORIST SYMBOLS DATABASE) ] {{DEFAULTSORT:Fassila, Sofiane}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Algerian al-Qaeda members]] {{crime-bio-stub}}

'''Vadim the Bold''' was a legendary chieftain of the [[Ilmen Slavs]] who led their struggle against [[Rurik]] and the [[Varangians]] in the 9th century.
According to the [[Nikon Chronicle]], a historic 16th-century Russian chronicle that covered events of 859–1520 CE, the Novgorodians broke into rebellion against [[Rurik]], their ruler, but his Varangian [[druzhina]] managed to quell the riots and murdered their leader, Vadim. The first Russian historian, [[Vasily Tatishchev]], conjectured that Vadim's mother was the elder daughter of [[Gostomysl]]. Hence, Vadim was Rurik's elder cousin and had a better claim to the throne.
==In Russian literature== After Tatischev's publications, Vadim became one of the most popular characters in the 18th-century [[Russian literature]]. [[Yakov Knyazhnin]], a leading playwright, penned a play in which he contrasted Vadim, a defender of [[Novgorod]]'s ancient freedom, with the authoritarian Rurik. When the play appeared in 1791, [[Catherine the Great]] was enraged, although she had fictionalized Vadim's struggle against Rurik in one of her own plays. Against the background of the [[French Revolution]], Knyazhnin was accused of [[Jacobinism]] and all printed copies of his play were to be burnt.
==Authenticity issues== In the 19th century, [[Sergey Solovyov]] and other major historians cast a doubt on the historicity and [[Authentication|authenticity]] of Vadim.<ref>[http://az.lib.ru/k/knjazhnin_j_b/text_0030.shtml "Vadim of Novgorod"]: The tragedy in verse in five acts. (Russian). [http://az.lib.ru/ The project "Collection of classics" Libraries Moshkova (Lib.ru / Classical)]. Accessed May 2011.</ref> Currently, he is considered a legendary personage. Yet his freedom-loving character appealed to the spirit of [[Romanticism]]. Three leading Russian poets of the era, [[Alexander Pushkin]], [[Vasily Zhukovsky]] and [[Mikhail Lermontov]], based their poems on the subject of Vadim's legendary exploits.
